elements.content: The 1:1 mixture of Co(Brhfpip) 2 and D1py 2 gave isomeric diazocobalt complexes, 1 and 2, formulated by [Co(Brhfpip) 2 (D1py 2 )] n . Complexes 1 and 2 have zigzag and linear chain structures by the cis and trans coordination of pyridine units in D1py 2 , respectively. After irradiation of microcrystalline samples, the generated carbene interacted with the cobalt ion to form ferromagnetic chains, 1c and 2c. Those isomeric chains exhibited slow magnetic relaxation with U eff = 93 and 87 K and H c = 20 and 13 kOe at 1.9 K for 1c and 2c, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The 1:1 mixture of Co(Brhfpip)  2  and D1py  2  gave isomeric diazocobalt complexes, 1 and 2, formulated by [Co(Brhfpip)  2 (D1py  2  )] n  . Complexes 1 and 2 have zigzag and linear chain structures by the cis and trans coordination of pyridine units in D1py  2 , respectively. After irradiation of microcrystalline samples, the generated carbene interacted with the cobalt ion to form ferromagnetic chains, 1c and 2c. Those isomeric chains exhibited slow magnetic relaxation with U eff = 93 and 87 K and H c = 20 and 13 kOe at 1.9 K for 1c and 2c, respectively.

elements.content: After irradiation of zigzag and linear chains formulated as [Co(Brhfpip) 2 (D1py 2 )] n , 1 and 2, in the crystalline state, the generated carbene interacted with the cobalt ion to form ferromagnetic chains, 1c and 2c. Those isomeric chains exhibited slow magnetic relaxation with U eff = 93 and 87 K and H c = 20 and 13 kOe at 1.9 K for 1c and 2c, respectively, and might function as a single-molecule magnet (SMM) rather than a single-chain magnet.
elements.clean_text: After irradiation of zigzag and linear chains formulated as [Co(Brhfpip)  2  (D1py  2  )]   n  , 1 and 2, in the crystalline state, the generated carbene interacted with the cobalt ion to form ferromagnetic chains, 1c and 2c. Those isomeric chains exhibited slow magnetic relaxation with U eff = 93 and 87 K and H c = 20 and 13 kOe at 1.9 K for 1c and 2c, respectively, and might function as a single-molecule magnet (SMM) rather than a single-chain magnet.

elements.content: Heterospin systems consisting of 3d spins of metal ions and 2p spins due to organic radicals and carbenes can provide unique molecule-based magnets by varying the combination of the chelating metal complexes (or metal ions) and the ligands carrying organic spins. The combination of the anisotropic cobalt(II) complexes (or ion) and diazomonopyridine derivative, D1py, where the diazo moiety is a precursor for carbene, led to new types of single-molecule magnets (SMMs) with a high effecitve activation barrier, U eff, which corresponds to |D|S 2; D and S are the anisotropic parameter and the spin quantum number, for reorientation of the magnetic moment. When diazodipyridine derivatives, D1py 2 , were used as photoresponsive magnetic couplers, the formation of a high-spin polymetallic chain after irradiation was expected. Actually, the combination of D1py 2 and isotropic metal complexes, CuII- and MnII(hfac)2 (hfac = hexafluoroacetylacetonato), was reported to provide ferro- and ferrimagnetic chains, respectively, after irradiation. In the combination of D1py 2 and anisotropic metal complexes, on the other hand, the low efficiency of photolysis in the solid state prevented investigation of their magnetic properties. A magnetic unianisotropic chain is known as a single-chain magnet (SCM). The activation barrier, Δeff, for SCM is expressed as the summation of a correlation length energy, Δl (=4JS 2; J is the exchange coupling parameter), and an anisotropic energy, Δa (=|D|S 2) in a finite-length region of the Ising model. Recently, it was found that a cyclic dinuclear cobalt(II) complex, [Co( tert -Buhfpip) 2 (D2py 2 )] 2 , was photolyzed in the crystalline state to form an SMM with U eff = 96 K. The finding that photolysis of the diazoCo(hfpip)2 complex in the crystalline state effectively took place allows application of the heterospin system to the study of polymetallic chains. In this study, D1py 2 was used, and 1:1 polymeric complexes of Co(Brhfpip) 2 with D1py 2 having zigzag and linear chain structures were successfully prepared. We report here the crystal structure of cobalt(II) complexes composed of D1py 2 and Co(Brhfpip) 2 and their magnetic behaviors before and after irradiation.
elements.clean_text: Heterospin systems consisting of 3d spins of metal ions and 2p spins due to organic radicals and carbenes can provide unique molecule-based magnets by varying the combination of the chelating metal complexes (or metal ions) and the ligands carrying organic spins. The combination of the anisotropic cobalt(II) complexes (or ion) and diazomonopyridine derivative, D1py, where the diazo moiety is a precursor for carbene, led to new types of single-molecule magnets (SMMs) with a high effecitve activation barrier, U eff, which corresponds to |D|S 2; D and S are the anisotropic parameter and the spin quantum number, for reorientation of the magnetic moment. When diazodipyridine derivatives, D1py  2 , were used as photoresponsive magnetic couplers, the formation of a high-spin polymetallic chain after irradiation was expected. Actually, the combination of D1py  2  and isotropic metal complexes, CuII- and MnII(hfac)2 (hfac = hexafluoroacetylacetonato), was reported to provide ferro- and ferrimagnetic chains, respectively, after irradiation. In the combination of D1py  2  and anisotropic metal complexes, on the other hand, the low efficiency of photolysis in the solid state prevented investigation of their magnetic properties. A magnetic unianisotropic chain is known as a single-chain magnet (SCM). The activation barrier, Δeff, for SCM is expressed as the summation of a correlation length energy, Δl (=4JS 2; J is the exchange coupling parameter), and an anisotropic energy, Δa (=|D|S 2) in a finite-length region of the Ising model. Recently, it was found that a cyclic dinuclear cobalt(II) complex, [Co(  tert  -Buhfpip)  2  (D2py  2  )]  2 , was photolyzed in the crystalline state to form an SMM with U eff = 96 K. The finding that photolysis of the diazoCo(hfpip)2 complex in the crystalline state effectively took place allows application of the heterospin system to the study of polymetallic chains. In this study, D1py  2  was used, and 1:1 polymeric complexes of Co(Brhfpip)  2  with D1py  2  having zigzag and linear chain structures were successfully prepared. We report here the crystal structure of cobalt(II) complexes composed of D1py  2  and Co(Brhfpip)  2  and their magnetic behaviors before and after irradiation.

elements.content: The solutions of D1py 2 and Co(Brhfpip) 2 were mixed at a 1:1 ratio under different conditions (I and II in S1 in the , SI) to afford two single crystals of 1:1 cobalt(II) complexes, 1 and 2, formulated by [Co(Brhfpip) 2 (D1py 2 )] n independently as dark orange chips and platelets, respectively. The selective recrystallizations for 1 and 2 were reproducible. The molecular structures of 1 and 2 revealed by X-ray crystallography are shown in Figure . In both complexes, 1 has a center of symmetry between the chains, while 2 has two centers of symmetry at the cobalt ions within the chain. The ligand D1py 2 coordinated to Co(Brhfpip) 2 in cis and trans configurations, forming zigzag and linear chains for 1 and 2, respectively. The cobalt ion units have compressed octahedral structures, in which the bond lengths between the cobalt ion and the axial ligands are 2.023 (r Co−O1) and 2.026 (r Co−O2) Å for 1 and 2.008 (r Co1−O) and 2.021 (r Co2−O) Å for 2. These are shorter by 0.18−0.20 Å for 1 and 0.13−0.22 Å for 2 compared with those for r Co−N. The dihedral angles (py−py) between the pyridine planes in the D1py 2 unit are 36.4° for 1 and 31.3° for 2, suggesting that the generated carbene spin after photolysis of diazo moieties effectively delocalized in both pyridine rings. The dihedral angles (py−xy) between the pyridine plane and the X−Y plane defined by four nitrogen atoms coordinating to the cobalt ion are 70.2 and 73.1° for 1. On the other hand, in 2, two kinds of cobalt pyridine units, A and B, having py−xy of 77.7 and 48.0°, respectively, existed alternately in the chain (Figure b). The observed difference in dihedral angles for units A and B might affect the magnetic exchange couplings between the cobalt ion and the generated carbene. The distances between the cobalt ions within the chain are 11.6 and 14.0 Å in 1 and 12.0 Å in 2, indicating that the intrachain Co−Co interactions might be insignificant. Each chain aligned parallel to the b axis in 1 and the b + c − a direction in 2 (Figure S1 in the ). In both complexes, no short distances to neighboring chains within 6.5 Å were observed, suggesting that the chains are magnetically isolated in the crystalline state. It is noted that the direction of the anisotropic axis due to the cobalt ion, which is assumed to be the direction of oxygen atoms in the Brhfpip ligand, has a large angle (62.7 and 64.8° for 1 and 69.1 and 71.4° for 2) toward the axis of the chain (parts b and e in Figure S1 in the ).
elements.clean_text: The solutions of D1py  2  and Co(Brhfpip)  2   were mixed at a 1:1 ratio under different conditions (I and II in S1 in the , SI) to afford two single crystals of 1:1 cobalt(II) complexes, 1 and 2, formulated by [Co(Brhfpip)  2  (D1py  2  )]   n   independently as dark orange chips and platelets, respectively. The selective recrystallizations for 1 and 2 were reproducible. The molecular structures of 1 and 2 revealed by X-ray crystallography are shown in Figure . In both complexes, 1 has a center of symmetry between the chains, while 2 has two centers of symmetry at the cobalt ions within the chain. The ligand D1py  2  coordinated to Co(Brhfpip)  2  in cis and trans configurations, forming zigzag and linear chains for 1 and 2, respectively. The cobalt ion units have compressed octahedral structures, in which the bond lengths between the cobalt ion and the axial ligands are 2.023 (r Co-O1) and 2.026 (r Co-O2) Å for 1 and 2.008 (r Co1-O) and 2.021 (r Co2-O) Å for 2. These are shorter by 0.18-0.20 Å for 1 and 0.13-0.22 Å for 2 compared with those for r Co-N. The dihedral angles (py-py) between the pyridine planes in the D1py  2  unit are 36.4° for 1 and 31.3° for 2, suggesting that the generated carbene spin after photolysis of diazo moieties effectively delocalized in both pyridine rings. The dihedral angles (py-xy) between the pyridine plane and the X-Y plane defined by four nitrogen atoms coordinating to the cobalt ion are 70.2 and 73.1° for 1. On the other hand, in 2, two kinds of cobalt pyridine units, A and B, having py-xy of 77.7 and 48.0°, respectively, existed alternately in the chain (Figure b). The observed difference in dihedral angles for units A and B might affect the magnetic exchange couplings between the cobalt ion and the generated carbene. The distances between the cobalt ions within the chain are 11.6 and 14.0 Å in 1 and 12.0 Å in 2, indicating that the intrachain Co-Co interactions might be insignificant. Each chain aligned parallel to the b axis in 1 and the b + c - a direction in 2 (Figure S1 in the ). In both complexes, no short distances to neighboring chains within 6.5 Å were observed, suggesting that the chains are magnetically isolated in the crystalline state. It is noted that the direction of the anisotropic axis due to the cobalt ion, which is assumed to be the direction of oxygen atoms in the Brhfpip ligand, has a large angle (62.7 and 64.8° for 1 and 69.1 and 71.4° for 2) toward the axis of the chain (parts b and e in Figure S1 in the ).

elements.content: Molecular structures of 1 (a) and 2 (b), represented by a ball-and-stick model (color code: cobalt, blue; carbon, gray; oxygen, red; nitrogen, light blue; bromine, wine red). Hydrogen atoms and trifluoromethyl groups are omitted for the sake of clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structures of 1 (a) and 2 (b), represented by a ball-and-stick model (color code: cobalt, blue; carbon, gray; oxygen, red; nitrogen, light blue; bromine, wine red). Hydrogen atoms and trifluoromethyl groups are omitted for the sake of clarity.

elements.content: The crystals were ground, spread over cellophane tape, and used as the sample for SQUID measurement. Photolysis with an argon laser (514 nm and 120 mW) of the diazo groups in complexes 1 and 2 effectively took place in a crystalline state to afford the corresponding cobalt carbene complexes, 1c and 2c. The progress of photolysis was followed by the magnetization measurement at 5 K and 5 kOe (Figure S2 in the ). Upon photolysis, the value of the magnetization steeply increased for 2 h and then increased gradually. After irradiation for ca. 20 h, the degrees of photolysis of the samples were determined to be ca. 88 and 86% for 1 and 2, respectively, by consumption of IR absorption at 2068 and 2064 cm−1 due to the diazo moieties after SQUID measurements.
elements.clean_text: The crystals were ground, spread over cellophane tape, and used as the sample for SQUID measurement. Photolysis with an argon laser (514 nm and 120 mW) of the diazo groups in complexes 1 and 2 effectively took place in a crystalline state to afford the corresponding cobalt carbene complexes, 1c and 2c. The progress of photolysis was followed by the magnetization measurement at 5 K and 5 kOe (Figure S2 in the ). Upon photolysis, the value of the magnetization steeply increased for 2 h and then increased gradually. After irradiation for ca. 20 h, the degrees of photolysis of the samples were determined to be ca. 88 and 86% for 1 and 2, respectively, by consumption of IR absorption at 2068 and 2064 cm-1 due to the diazo moieties after SQUID measurements.

elements.content: The direct-current (dc) and alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility data before and after irradiation of the microcrystalline sample of 1 and 2 were collected in the temperature ranges of 1.9−50 and 1.9−30 K, respectively. The χmol T vs T plots were obtained at a constant dc field of 5 kOe in the range of 25−50 K and 0.5 kOe below 30 K for 1 and 1 kOe below 30 K for 2 (Figure a). Before irradiation of 1, the χmol T values were nearly constant at 2.0 cm3 K mol−1 in the temperature range and were in good agreement with that for a dilute paramagnet, while after irradiation, they increased gradually below 50 K upon cooling, increased abruptly below 20 K, reached a maximum (120 cm3 K mol−1) at 12 K, and then decreased. The large maximum value indicated that the generated carbene and the cobalt ion in the complex units interacted ferromagnetically to form a high-spin chain. The decrease in the χT values below 12 K might be due to an effect of the zero-field-splitting parameter owing to a spin−orbit coupling in the cobalt ion. Complex 2c also showed a thermal profile on the χmol T vs T plot similar to that for 1c and formed a ferromagnetic chain after irradiation. However, the maximum χmol T value was 20 cm3 K mol−1 at 13.5 K, which was one-sixth that for 1c, indicating that the magnetic correlation length for 2c below 20 K was shorter than that for 1c and the ferromagnetic coupling (J trans) between the cobalt ion and the carbene for 2c was weaker than that (J cis) for 1c. The difference of magnetic coupling (J cis > J trans) in the cis and trans isomers was consistent with those in analogous chains of [Cu- and Mn(hfac)2 1c] n . In addition, the observed difference in the magnitude of the magnetic coupling might be due to the dihedral angles (py−xy) for 1 and 2. As revealed by the molecular structure analysis, 2 consisted of two units, units A and B, having different dihedral angles. Because the dihedral angles for unit A were close to those for 1, a weak interaction would be caused by unit B. Therefore, 2c might be a magnetically alternating chain consisting of units A and B with magnetic exchange coupling constants, J trans1 and J trans2 (J trans1 > J trans2 > 0), respectively (Figure S1f in the ). Subsequently, the dc magnetizations, M mol, for 1c and 2c were measured in the range −50 to +50 kOe and 1.9−3.5 K with a field sweep rate of 0.35 kOe s−1. Interestingly, large hysteresis loops relating to the field were observed below 3.5 K in 1c and 2c. The width of the hysteresis loops increased with decreasing temperature (Figure S3 in the ). The coercive force (H c) and remnant magnetization (M r) at 1.9 K for 1c and 2c were 20 and 13 kOe and 1.0 × 104 and 7.5 × 103 cm3 Oe mol−1, respectively (Figure b). The hysteresis depending on the temperature suggested the formation of a SMM or SCM.

The χmol T vs T plots were obtained at a constant dc field of 5 kOe in the range of 25-50 K and 0.5 kOe below 30 K for 1 and 1 kOe below 30 K for 2 (Figure a). Before irradiation of 1, the χmol T values were nearly constant at 2.0 cm3 K mol-1 in the temperature range and were in good agreement with that for a dilute paramagnet, while after irradiation, they increased gradually below 50 K upon cooling, increased abruptly below 20 K, reached a maximum (120 cm3 K mol-1) at 12 K, and then decreased. The large maximum value indicated that the generated carbene and the cobalt ion in the complex units interacted ferromagnetically to form a high-spin chain. Complex 2c also showed a thermal profile on the χmol T vs T plot similar to that for 1c and formed a ferromagnetic chain after irradiation. However, the maximum χmol T value was 20 cm3 K mol-1 at 13.5 K, which was one-sixth that for 1c, indicating that the magnetic correlation length for 2c below 20 K was shorter than that for 1c and the ferromagnetic coupling (J trans) between the cobalt ion and the carbene for 2c was weaker than that (J cis) for 1c. The difference of magnetic coupling (J cis > J trans) in the cis and trans isomers was consistent with those in analogous chains of [Cu- and Mn(hfac)2 1c] n . elements.content: Plots of (a) χmol T vs T for 1 (black cross, at 5 kOe), 1c (red square, at 5 kOe; red circle, at 0.5 kOe), and 2c (blue square, at 5 kOe) and (b) field dependence of M mol at 1.9 K for 1c (red) and 2c (blue).
elements.clean_text: 2  Plots of (a) χmol T vs T for 1 (black cross, at 5 kOe), 1c (red square, at 5 kOe; red circle, at 0.5 kOe), and 2c (blue square, at 5 kOe) and (b) field dependence of M mol at 1.9 K for 1c (red) and 2c (blue).

elements.content: To investigate the slow magnetic relaxation in more detail, ac magnetic susceptibility experiments at a zero dc field with a 3.9 Oe ac field in the frequency of 1−1000 Hz were carried out (Figures and S4 in the ). Well-resolved χ′ and χ′′ signals (in-phase and out-of-phase components of ac magnetic susceptibilities, respectively) with a frequency dependence were observed, indicating that the complexes have a slow magnetic relaxation for reorientation of the magnetic moment. The χ′′ signals at each frequency showed maxima above 4 K, and the peak-top temperatures shifted lower as the frequency decreased. The thermal profiles of both signals for 1c and 2c were similar, but the signal intensities and the shapes of the peaks were largely different. 1c showed strong signals at each frequency, while 2c showed weak and broad peaks with a shoulder at the high-temperature side, indicating that the plural components existed. From Arrhenius plots (Figure S5 in the ), the activation energy for reorientation of the magnetic moment and the preexponential factor, τ0, were estimated to be 93 K and 2.4 × 10−9 s for 1c and 87 K and 4.4 × 10−9 s for the major compornent of 2c. It is noted that the obtained values of the activation energy were close to each other.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the slow magnetic relaxation in more detail, ac magnetic susceptibility experiments at a zero dc field with a 3.9 Oe ac field in the frequency of 1-1000 Hz were carried out (Figures  and S4 in the ). Well-resolved χ' and χ'' signals (in-phase and out-of-phase components of ac magnetic susceptibilities, respectively) with a frequency dependence were observed, indicating that the complexes have a slow magnetic relaxation for reorientation of the magnetic moment. The χ'' signals at each frequency showed maxima above 4 K, and the peak-top temperatures shifted lower as the frequency decreased. The thermal profiles of both signals for 1c and 2c were similar, but the signal intensities and the shapes of the peaks were largely different. 1c showed strong signals at each frequency, while 2c showed weak and broad peaks with a shoulder at the high-temperature side, indicating that the plural components existed. From Arrhenius plots (Figure S5 in the ), the activation energy for reorientation of the magnetic moment and the preexponential factor, τ0, were estimated to be 93 K and 2.4 × 10-9 s for 1c and 87 K and 4.4 × 10-9 s for the major compornent of 2c. It is noted that the obtained values of the activation energy were close to each other.

elements.content: Plots of χ′′ vs T of 1c and 2c (inset) with a 3.9 Oe ac field oscillating at listed frequencies. The solid lines are visual guides.
elements.clean_text: 3  Plots of χ'' vs T of 1c and 2c (inset) with a 3.9 Oe ac field oscillating at listed frequencies. The solid lines are visual guides.

elements.content: In 1c and 2c, the magnetic behaviors observed in dc and ac magnetic susceptibility experiments are typical profiles for SMM and SCM with uniaxial anisotropy. The result that the activation barriers for 1c and 2c with different magnitudes of J are comparable may suggest that the magnetic properties of 1c and 2c are SMM-like rather than SCM-like. The observed unique magnetic behaviors for 1c and 2c chains might be due to the local anisotropic axis at the cobalt ion having the large angle (63−71°) toward the axis of the chain.
elements.clean_text: In 1c and 2c, the magnetic behaviors observed in dc and ac magnetic susceptibility experiments are typical profiles for SMM and SCM with uniaxial anisotropy. The result that the activation barriers for 1c and 2c with different magnitudes of J are comparable may suggest that the magnetic properties of 1c and 2c are SMM-like rather than SCM-like. The observed unique magnetic behaviors for 1c and 2c chains might be due to the local anisotropic axis at the cobalt ion having the large angle (63-71°) toward the axis of the chain.

elements.content: Quantitative analysis of an analogous heterospin chain using stable N,N-dipyridylaminoxyl and the preparation of a polymeric heterospin complex having the same local anisotropic axis as the direction of the chain are in progress.
elements.clean_text: Quantitative analysis of an analogous heterospin chain using stable N,N-dipyridylaminoxyl and the preparation of a polymeric heterospin complex having the same local anisotropic axis as the direction of the chain are in progress.

elements.content: Crystallographic details in CIF format (CCDC 735762 and 735763 for 1 and 2, respectively), crystal data (Table S1), crystal packing (Figure S1), M vs time plots (Figure S2), M mol vs H below 3.6 K (Figure S3), χ′ mol vs T (Figure S4), and Arrhenius plots (Figure S5). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title: Magnetic Behaviors of Heterospin Chains Consisting of Cobalt(II) Complexes and Dipyridylcarbenes
